utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Whatcha doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m attempting to view my work as a fleeting peripheral image so as to engage the superior colliculus of my brain.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Interesting. I usually just have coffee. You’ve been up all night?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is it morning?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Then I’ve been up all night.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: And you’re stuck?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why else would a person try to engage their superior colliculus?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, sorry, sweetie, I can’t help you till I’ve had my coffee.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny, I told you if you don’t put him in his crate at night he just runs around the apartment.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What is he doing now?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Mmm, he’s either isolating the terms of his formula and examining them individually, or looking for the alligator that swallowed his hand after Peter Pan cut it off.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Captain Hook’s hand was eaten by a crocodile, not an alligator. If you’re going to mock me, at least get your facts straight.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Aye, aye, Captain.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can’t see it! It just won’t coalesce.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Maybe you need a fresh start.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re right. It’s a great idea, Leonard. Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Electrons move through graphene, act as if they have no mass…

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: How long has he been stuck?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Intellectually about 30 hours. Emotionally about 29 years.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Unit cell contains two carbon atoms. Interior angle of a hexagon is 120 degrees.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Have you tried rebooting him?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I think it’s a firmware problem.

utterance.speaker: Raj (arriving)
utterance.content: Hey, it’s Disco Night at the Moonlight Roller Rink in Glendale tonight. Who’s up for getting down?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, that’s perfect. Bernadette’s been hocking me to take her roller skating.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I think Penny likes to skate. The four of us could double.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What could be better? We’re in.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Great. It’s not like I brought it up because I wanted to go.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You can come with us.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, it’s okay. I don’t have to go. I’m happy just to guide you and your ladies to suitable entertainment choices. I’m a walking brown Yelp.com.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Structure, constant structure. One atom…

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Boy, he’s really gone, isn’t he?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, this morning he used a stick of butter as deodorant.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I thought I smelled popcorn.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Pattern is the same as fermions, travels on the pathways, hexagonal, it’s always hexagonal…

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I haven’t seen him this stuck since he tried to figure out the third Matrix movie.

utterance.speaker: Raj (as Sheldon reaches out and grabs from his plate)
utterance.content: Hey, those are my lima beans!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not lima beans, carbon atoms.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: But if I don’t eat my lima beans, I can’t have my cookie.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Here, you want my peas?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Peas! Perfect, they can be electrons.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Want my corn?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Don’t be ridiculous. What would I do with corn?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So roller skating, should we all grab a bite to eat first?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Good. P.F. Chang’s? My mom has coupons.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Great. Your mom’s not coming, right?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Not this time, I promise.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, just to be clear, roller skating was my idea, and I’m very unhappy that you turned it into a double date, and I hope you both fall on your asses and break your coccyxes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The plural of coccyx is coccyges.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Screw you. Give me back my lima beans.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, my God, have you ever been so embarrassed?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Not recently.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I don’t know which was lamer, their roller-skating or their disco dancing.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: For me, the worst part was when people saw us leave with them.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You had some nice moves out there, Howard.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thanks. You, too.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah. Did you notice all the people looking at us?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Not really. I was in my boogie zone.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: When Howard tried to do the splits…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Shh.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sorry. I’m moving a little slow. I think I bruised my coccyx.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, poor baby.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Don’t tell Koothrappali. After you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, what a gentleman. Hey, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, my God! Are you…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good Lord! You’re ruining everything!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, damn.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Do I look okay?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Don’t bark at me. I fell, too.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, you’ve been falling all night. You’re used to it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, what the hell are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The same thing I’ve been doing for three days. Trying to figure out why electrons behave as if they have no mass when travelling through a graphene sheet.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: With marbles?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I needed something bigger than peas, now, didn’t I?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Sheldon, when was the last time you got any sleep?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t know, two, three days. Not important. I don’t need sleep, I need answers. I need to determine where in this swamp of unbalanced formulas squatteth the toad of truth.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Toad of truth? Is that a physics thing?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, that’s a crazy thing.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Okay, Sheldon. What happens to our neuroreceptors when we don’t get enough REM sleep?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: They lose their sensitivity to serotonin and norepinephrine.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Which leads to…?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Impaired cognitive function.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Right, so march in there, brush your teeth and go to bed.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But I don’t want to go to bed.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I’m going to count to three. One…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, all right.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That was amazing how you handled him.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I know how to deal with stubborn children. My mother used to run an illegal day care centre in our basement.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Leonard, you’re… you’re giggling in your sleep.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s not me, it’s my new ringtone. The Joker from Batman.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, it creeps me out.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Me, too, but I paid three bucks for it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Just answer the phone.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hello. Yeah, I’m Leonard Hofstadter. Yeah, yeah, he’s my roommate. Oh, God, is he okay? Yeah, alright, alright, I’ll be right there.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon’s escaped and is terrorizing the village.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay. Have fun.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hi. I’m Dr. Hofstadter. Where is he?

utterance.speaker: Security Guard
utterance.content: Ball pit.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thanks for not calling the cops.

utterance.speaker: Security Guard
utterance.content: Oh, hey, it’s no big deal. My sister’s got a kid who’s special.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, well, he’s extra special. Hey, Shelly. What you doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Size ratio was all wrong. Couldn’t visualize it. Needed bigger carbon atoms.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sure, sure. How did you get into this place?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Back door has a five-pin tumbler system, single-circuit alarm. Child’s play. You can start sorting protons and neutrons while I build carbon atoms.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I don’t think so. We need to go home now.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But I’m still working.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If you don’t come out of there, I’m going to have to drag you out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You can try, but you’ll never catch me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: For God’s sakes. Sheldon, come here!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (popping his head up)
utterance.content: Bazinga. Bazinga. Bazinga. Bazinga. Bazinga.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard and Penny. Leonard and Penny.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (Waking up as Penny screams)
utterance.content: What! What, what, what?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard and Penny.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I have good news.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: And you had to barge in here and wake us up in the middle of the night?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Your cell phone was off.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Because we didn’t want to be disturbed.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And that didn’t work out, did it?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, what do you want?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I came to tell you I’ve got the answer.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really? You figured out the graphene problem?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no, I’m still hopelessly stuck on that, but I figured out how to figure it out.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, you know what, Leonard, I know I said I could handle your roommate, but I was wrong. We’re going to have to break up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: Penny (as Sheldon sits on the bed)
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Einstein.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, I’m going to need a little more.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Albert Einstein.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Keep going.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: When Albert Einstein came up with special relativity, he was working at the patent office.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, you’re going to go work at the patent office?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Don’t be absurd. That’s in Washington. You know I could never live in a city whose streets are laid out in a wheel-and-spoke pattern. No. I’m going to find a similarly menial job where my basal ganglia are occupied with a routine task, freeing my prefrontal cortex to work quietly in the background on my problem.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sounds like a great plan.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course it is. Even talking to you is sufficiently menial that I can feel the proverbial juices starting to flow.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, well, thanks for sharing with us. Good night.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re welcome. Good night to you, too. Oh, by the way, I was watching you sleep for a moment, and I noticed that your snoring seems to be worse when you’re on your back.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Leonard doesn’t snore.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, I wasn’t talking to Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Told you.

utterance.speaker: Employment Office Assistant
utterance.content: So, Mr. Cooper, you’re looking for a job.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A menial job. Like yours.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Why, thank you for noticing. I’m Menial Employee of the Month. Do you have a particular field in mind?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I do. For thousands of years, the lowest classes of the human race have spent their lives labouring to erect monuments under the lash of their betters, until finally they dropped down and became one with the dust through which they trudged. Do you have anything like that?

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Shouldn’t you check your database?

utterance.speaker: Assistant (clicks her keyboard a few times)
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You didn’t really type.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: I didn’t really have to. So, how about construction?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, that would be good! Sawing, hammering, eating out of a lunch pail as my working-class fellows and I sit perched precariously on a girder high above the metropolis.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: No, no. This is putting up sheetrock at a housing project in Rosemead.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I could do that.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: One question.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What’s sheetrock?

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Moving on. How about doing deliveries for a florist?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That seems acceptable.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Do you have your own car?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t drive.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Of course you don’t. Mr. Cooper, let me just ask you a question. What was your last job?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Senior theoretical particle physicist at CalTech, focusing on M theory, or, in layman’s terms, string theory.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: I see. Just give me a second. Security!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I’ll get those drinks started for you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (appearing in an apron and carrying a tray)
utterance.content: Behind you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, what the hell are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m trying to get these tables cleared. We’re slammed.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, wait, wait, no, wait. Wh.. what are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A reasonable question. I asked myself, what is the most mind-numbing, pedestrian job conceivable, and three answers came to mind, uh, toll booth attendant, an Apple Store genius, and what Penny does. Now, since I don’t like touching other people’s coins, and I refuse to contribute to the devaluation of the word genius, here I am.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You just, you just walked in and they hired you, just like that?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, heavens, no. Since I don’t need to be paid, I didn’t need to be hired. I simply came in, picked up a tray, and started working for the man. Let me get that plate out of your way.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, this is ridiculous.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is it? Just a moment ago I had a minor epiphany regarding the polymer degradation phenomenon while scraping congealed nachos off a plate. Bernadette, table 10 wants their check.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Thanks, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, wait, this isn’t even what I do. I’m a waitress, not a busboy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re right. That is more menial. Hello, I’m Sheldon. I’ll be your server today. I don’t recommend the salmon. I saw it in the kitchen.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, one bacon cheeseburger, breaking two Jewish dietary restrictions simultaneously, kudos. Beer-battered fish and chips. Now, here’s your tartar sauce. I also brought you salsa. It’s a little unconventional, but I think you’ll like it. It’s zingy. And for you, Factory Burrito Grande, no cheese, no sour cream, no ugly consequences from your lactose intolerance. Bon appétit.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hang on. Black beans, not pinto beans?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Double guacamole?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No cilantro?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nope.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Lettuce shredded, not chopped?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yep.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You understand why I’m doing this to you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I do.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’ll be all. That was fun.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: How long can he keep this up?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I heard about this professor at MIT who melted down, bought a van, and spent the rest of his life as a mobile dog groomer.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: He never went back to the university?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Only to shampoo Professor Chambourg’s shih tzu.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Sheesh.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I bet if we all chipped in, we could buy Sheldon a van.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: But he’s afraid of dogs.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s the only thing wrong with that plan.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, guys, sorry you had to wait, but we are swamped. What’s this?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon took our order.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon doesn’t work here.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, honey, not to complain, but we were starting to think you didn’t either.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (drops tray. A nearby table claps)
utterance.content: Is that really necessary? Good Lord. The interference pattern in the fracture. The motion of the wave through the molecular structure. I’ve been looking at it all wrong. I can’t consider the electrons as particles. They move through the graphene as a wave. It’s a wave! The moment to applaud would be now. Troglodytes.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, where are you going? Aren’t you going to clean this up?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I don’t work here.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Happy now?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m on a cloud. Swing me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, come here.
